context: Beyoncé Giselle Knowles-Carter (/biːˈjɒnseɪ/ bee-YON-say) (born September 4, 1981) is an American singer, songwriter, record producer and actress. Born and raised in <a3_0>Houston, Texas<a3_0/>, she performed in various <a1_0>singing and dancing<a1_0/> competitions as a child, and rose to fame <a0_0>in the <a4_0><a8_0>late 1990s<a8_0/><a4_0/><a0_0/> as <a9_0><a13_0>lead singer<a13_0/><a9_0/> of R&B girl-group <a5_0>Destiny's Child<a5_0/>. Managed by her father, <a7_0>Mathew Knowles<a7_0/>, the group became one of the world's best-selling girl groups of all time. Their hiatus saw the release of Beyoncé's debut album, <a6_0><a10_0><a14_0>Dangerously in Love<a14_0/><a10_0/><a6_0/> (<a2_0><a11_0>2003<a11_0/><a2_0/>), which established her as a solo artist worldwide, earned <a12_0>five<a12_0/> Grammy Awards and featured the Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles "Crazy in Love" and "Baby Boy".
